utterance: Marcel Schreier: I have a kind of almost a kind of fundamental concern. So first of all I don't want to discredit research on nitrogen reduction because I think from a scientific perspective it's fascinating. This dinitrogen bond is fascinating. But when we then look at an engineering perspective when we think about what we need to do to do an electrochemical transformation of nitrogen now we just think at scale right. We need to bring in dinitrogen and we need to bring in protons and we need to bring in current. So we need obviously it's kind of a triple phase boundary or or kind of a gas diffusion electrode kind of design. This will be very difficult especially for bringing in the gaseous species which is very weakly soluble. I think that's where people struggle. Whereas if we are generating hydrogen in an electrolyzer we have no transport problem we just can bring water to the reaction site with very high transport rates generate hydrogen get a gas and then convert it together with a second gas nitrogen in a Haber-Bosch process. So I just think when we look at this from this engineering perspective right this need for a triple phase boundary compared to the ease of generating hydrogen electrochemically we may find ourselves in a situation where when we want to do it at scale we may find it hard to compete with a coupled Haber-Bosch and electrolyzer design. I don't know what you guys think.

annotations.ask question: Marcel requests the group's thoughts on his concern and suggested approach.

utterance: Andrew Teixeira: I might have missed a little bit of that but so you're saying that because the electrochemical route requires the addition of the proton there I mean when I think about that compared to the traditional Haber-Bosch you do need the net thermodynamic states are going to be the same so the net driving forces are the same. So are you saying it's an engineering challenge to get them all co-located on the active site?

annotations.ask question: The speaker is requesting clarification or confirmation of Marcel Schreier's statement.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker is also expanding on the idea by comparing the electrochemical route with the traditional Haber-Bosch process.

utterance: Marcel Schreier: a transport where we need the triple phase boundary whereas in a classical catalytic environment we have very good transport between two gases going to an iron-based catalytic site and then turning over to ammonia.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on an existing idea, providing more details about the challenges of achieving a certain process.
annotations.offer feedback: The speaker provides specific insights into the technical difficulties of an approach, which can be seen as feedback.

utterance: Andrew Teixeira: I mean it's been you could argue that that transport has been fine-tuned over you know decades at least for development there of the the fluidized bed technology to get there and I don't know to me it sounds like it's not a scientific barrier it's a technical question of how are we going to do it as opposed to saying even if we do get it it won't be efficient.

annotations.develop idea: Andrew is expanding on Marcel's idea by providing a perspective on the transport challenges and suggesting it's more of a technical issue than a scientific one.
annotations.supportive response: Andrew is providing a positive evaluation of the situation by framing it as a technical challenge rather than a scientific one, which is supportive of the discussion.

utterance: Haotian Wang: I think it's it's I agree with Marcel it's a big problem but I also agree with Andrew that it could be solved. Like we can take examples from let's say oxygen reduction in fuel cell. They also need this type of triple phase boundaries but they can deliver very high current density which means that you can also deliver very high production rate per area of your electrode right. But the challenge here now is we don't have as a platinum as efficient in ORR as an unknown catalyst we can have for NRR. That's I think will be the critical challenge here to deliver the the scale that you mentioned to compete with Haber-Bosch.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on existing ideas by providing examples (oxygen reduction in fuel cells) and discussing challenges related to NRR and competing with Haber-Bosch.
annotations.supportive response: The speaker agrees with Marcel and Andrew, providing a supportive response to their ideas and further discussion.

utterance: Oana Luca: Sorry. I just want to add a bit of a kind of organic chemist perspective on the matter. I feel like you know we're asked to dream big right and the topic is beyond CO2 and you know come up with the craziest idea we can come up with. And you know on one hand from a chemistry perspective the nitrogen molecule doesn't have a dipole so it's really hard to activate for you at a surface at a molecule you name it. But on the other hand you know I think that there are from a synthetic perspective there are a lot of other products that could be made from a nitrogen reduction process and so you know if that is a way to frame the question not necessarily in terms of replacing Haber-Bosch which we know that is difficult but maybe adding a different kind of value to a process and so something that comes to mind is capturing carbon dioxide converting it to formaldehyde then making ammonia electrocatalytically and there are some systems that do this and then just adding a cyanide source and making amino acids. You know these are basic building blocks for organic synthesis and pharmaceutical science and you know these discussions today have really kind of catalyzed this these ideas where you know maybe we just need to think a little bit bigger right and you know Haber-Bosch is extraordinarily difficult to make an argument against but maybe there are other ways to frame the problem as an opportunity in a different context.

annotations.propose new idea: Oana Luca introduces new ideas for products from nitrogen reduction, such as making amino acids.
annotations.develop idea: She expands on these ideas by discussing potential applications in organic synthesis and pharmaceutical science.

utterance: Chris Jones: So I want to throw out something about BECCS. I don't know how many folks have talked about thought about that technology. I find it fascinating from an engineering perspective because one of the interesting things about biomass as an energy source or a feedstock for anything is that it's very distributed. So if you manage start to think about BECCS as a power source as well as a way to produce negative emissions, you're now talking about very distributed CO2 or carbon storage. And so that leads me to thinking about a future landscape that has either a massive amount of CO2 pipelines if we're going to sequester CO2 geologically or a massive reliance on biochar and the associated costs with shipping solids around for sequestration. And so I'm just I'm unsure which of those two is is lower hanging fruit and more likely to be attainable in the in the short term because both from a systems engineering and logistics perspective seem complex to me. But if you look at climate models, there's always a massive amount of BECCS that's suggested as a solution for our negative emissions challenge. And in principle the two parts are there, bioenergy and carbon capture and sequestration, but putting them all together into a system seems really challenging to me.

annotations.develop idea: Chris expands on the concept of BECCS, discussing its potential and challenges from an engineering perspective.
annotations.ask question: Chris expresses uncertainty about the best approach to implementing BECCS, asking for input from others.
annotations.critical response: Chris provides a critical analysis of the challenges associated with BECCS, questioning its feasibility.

utterance: Phil Milner: I can jump in with a thought that I've discussed with one of my colleagues, Jeff Coates who's a big CO2 to polymers researcher about trying to do it's something we're not doing anything with this. It's two chemists talking but about doing you know BECCS but where the instead of sequestration you you then feed the CO2 you capture into a CO2 polymerization site and you essentially attach a biomass to CO2 unit onto your CO2 polymer facility and you can use the energy perhaps to you can make this little self-sustained essentially factory. I don't know if the economics of that could ever become reasonable but that's something we've thought about as a way to avoid the like you said this landscape of CO2 piping seems unreasonable to me that we're going to have all these pipes running all over just moving CO2 underground but I don't know what your thoughts are about you know more about this than I do.

annotations.propose new idea: The speaker introduces a novel approach to utilizing CO2 in a polymerization process as an alternative to sequestration.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker elaborates on the proposed idea, discussing its potential implementation, challenges, and benefits.
